author: Grimms
text: In a village dwelt a poor old woman, who had gathered together a dish of beans and wanted to cook them.

author: Grimms
text: So she made a fire on her hearth, and that it might burn the quicker, she lighted it with a handful of straw.

author: Grimms
text: When she was emptying the beans into the pan, one dropped without her observing it, and lay on the ground beside a straw, and soon afterwards a burning coal from the fire leapt down to the two.

author: Grimms
text: Then the straw began and said: "Dear friends, from whence do you come here?"

author: Grimms
text: The coal replied: "I fortunately sprang out of the fire, and if I had not escaped by sheer force, my death would have been certain,--I should have been burnt to ashes."

author: Grimms
text: The bean said: "I too have escaped with a whole skin, but if the old woman had got me into the pan, I should have been made into broth without any mercy, like my comrades."

author: Grimms
text: "And would a better fate have fallen to my lot?" said the straw.

author: Grimms
text: "The old woman has destroyed all my brethren in fire and smoke; she seized sixty of them at once, and took their lives.

author: Grimms
text: I luckily slipped through her fingers."

author: Grimms
text: "But what are we to do now?" said the coal.

author: Grimms
text: "I think," answered the bean, "that as we have so fortunately escaped death, we should keep together like good companions, and lest a new mischance should overtake us here, we should go away together, and repair to a foreign country."

author: Grimms
text: The proposition pleased the two others, and they set out on their way together.

author: Grimms
text: Soon, however, they came to a little brook, and as there was no bridge or foot-plank, they did not know how they were to get over it.

author: Grimms
text: The straw hit on a good idea, and said: "I will lay myself straight across, and then you can walk over on me as on a bridge."

author: Grimms
text: The straw therefore stretched itself from one bank to the other, and the coal, who was of an impetuous disposition, tripped quite boldly on to the newly-built bridge.

author: Grimms
text: But when she had reached the middle, and heard the water rushing beneath her, she was after all, afraid, and stood still, and ventured no farther.

author: Grimms
text: The straw, however, began to burn, broke in two pieces, and fell into the stream.

author: Grimms
text: The coal slipped after her, hissed when she got into the water, and breathed her last.

author: Grimms
text: The bean, who had prudently stayed behind on the shore, could not but laugh at the event, was unable to stop, and laughed so heartily that she burst.

author: Grimms
text: It would have been all over with her, likewise, if, by good fortune, a tailor who was travelling in search of work, had not sat down to rest by the brook.

author: Grimms
text: As he had a compassionate heart he pulled out his needle and thread, and sewed her together.

author: Grimms
text: The bean thanked him most prettily, but as the tailor used black thread, all beans since then have a black seam.
